title: Project Research Bible: Aesthetics of Evil
text:
Abstract
In medieval bestiaries, there are two classes of evil represented by beasts; those which deceive and those which generate fear and death. Among the first class of beasts, those which are notable for their abilities to deceive, there are three kinds of deception: these are noted by the camouflages of the chameleon, accurate imitations of the manticore, and the “seductive skills of sirens”. While we might think this to be a medieval taxonomy of epistemic harms only, the kinds of epistemic harms the medievalists worried about are not far off from contemporary epistemic harms and risks; misinformation, false and inauthentic narratives, and bullshit.

title: Gut Reactions
text:
What is their significance?

Contribute to reasoning, action, and the election of ends.
Triggered by judgments and amenable to cultural influence.
Central to our comprehension of morality.

Consider internal systems of categorization, memory, attention, and reasoning (Processing Mode Theory):

Easier to recall events when in emotional states that are congruent with those events we are recalling (Bower 1981)
Positive emotions tend to promote the use of stereotypes (Bless, Schwarz, & Kemmelmeier, 1996)
Positive emotions help us to reason in ways that are open-minded, optimistic, and creative. Easier time problem solving novel applications of familiar materials (Isen, Daubman, & Nowicki, 1987)
Negative emotions promote more narrow attentional focus. Anxiety makes us attend to threatening objects (MacLeod & Mathews, 1991; Ohman, Flykt, & Esteves, 2001)
Sadness makes us more pessimistic and sensitive to our flaws (Alloy & Abrahamson, 1988)

title: Epistemic Injustice
text:
Power
Active and Passive powers

Power that is realized in action
Power that is being realized even when it is not being realized in action

Social vs. structural powers

Social power is power exercised (actively or passively) by one or more social agents.
But social power depends on practical coordination among social agents in a net-like organization. In such a case then, it is power that is never in one person’s hands alone.

title: Epistemic Injustice
text:
Identity Power
Central to social power is identity power since social power is dependent on the kinds of social exchanges that are possible between agents.
At the center of this are testimonial exchanges which rely on “shared imaginative conceptions of social identity:” identity powers.
Faulty judgments of a speaker will hinder these kinds of exchanges. We can apply this to the case of the victim. The victim is not able to defend her belief that she is not a victim because her judgment of her friend as speaker hinders her ability to explain herself. Additionally, her friend’s faulty judgment of her as a speaker also hinders her friend’s ability to accept her explanation.

title: Black authenticity and commodified realness: effects of controlling images and colourism
text:
Controlling images “are designed to make racism, sexism, poverty, and other forms of social injustice appear to be natural, normal, and inevitable parts of everyday life” (Collins 2000, 77).


What are the purposes of controlling images?
But if we broaden the label, then controlling images are designed to justify marginalizing some members of society.


Cultural production in context: the case of rap music

White corporate owners capitalized on the realness and rawness of rap music and used the artists’ and music’s authenticity as a marketing strategy. (layb20?)


This process was finalized with mainstream consumption in the 1990s with the 1996 Telecommunications act

radio stations were consolidated from locally independent radio stations and labels to national conglomerates.
music labels were consolidated from locally independent music labels to national conglomerates.

This meant that radio airplay format and songs were standardized.
Additionally, the markets which justified these consoladations where 60-80% white [Bialik, Carl. 2005. “Is the Conventional Wisdom Correct in Measuring Hip-Hop Audience?” Wall Street Journal, May 5. Accessed May 1, 2013. http://online.wsj. com/news/articles/SB111521814339424546; Kitwana, Bakari. 2002. The Hip Hop Generation: Young Blacks and the Crises in African American Culture. New York: Basic Civitas Books.; Rose, Tricia. 2008. The Hip Hop Wars: What We Talk about When We Talk about Hip Hop And Why It Matters. New York: Basic Books.].
Artists on their part began to equate ‘artist legitimacy’ with ‘commercial success’ [Lena, Jennifer C. 2006. “Social Context and Musical Content: Rap Music, 1979-1995.” Social Forces 85 (1): 479–495.].
As a result, these artists started to sell stereotypical beliefs about blackness back to a consumer base.

title: Introduction
text:
According to reductionism in personal identity, personal constitution, what defines the persistence of the human person over time, is reducible to psychological states being bound together. Causlism is the most popular account that explains the constitution of these psychological states. Accordingly to the causalist account, an object A at time T\(_1\) is identical to object B at time T\(_2\) as long as we can draw a continuous line from object A at time T\(_1\) to object B at time T\(_2\).
Narrativists have argued that such accounts undermine our concepts of agency and moral responsibility, failing to explain attributions of praise or blame in response to an agent’s actions. This is because they offer no way to define the line as beginning at T\(_1\) and ending at T\(_2\). Christine (kors89?) proposes a practical conception of narrative identity. Accordingly, an agent is a person who uses narrative to define their own constitution. She calls this the self-constitution model of personal identity.

title: Narrative Identity Korsgaard
text: Christine (kors89?) has argued that that Derek (parf87?)‘s Reasons and Persons defends an account of identity on which a person is primarily a locus of experience (kors89?). Kantians and Utilitarians have differeing conceptions of agency. For the Utilitarian, agency is a form of experience. As such, while the utilitarian asks ’what should be done for them?’, the Kantian asks ‘what ought they do?’. Korsgaard goes on to argue that focusing on what an agent does, rather than their experiences, will lead to a drastically different concept of identity. One which she calls ‘practical’.

Pohlhaus 2014, 105 “Speaker assumes a sort of ‘truncated’ or ‘circumscribed’ Subjectivity
Beauvoir 1952, status as the ‘other’



relegated to the role of epistemic other, being treated as though the range of one’s subject capacities is merely derivative [Pohlhaus 2014, 107]


Subject are reduced to attending only to that which stems from the perpetrator’s subjectivity



Epistemic “derivatization” -> Compulsory Representation -> Unique form of Epistemic Exclusion

the others capacities as a subject are reduced to attending only to that which stems from the perpetrator’s subjectivity, so that anything the victim might try to express that exceeds the range of the perpetrator’s subjectivity is actively prohibited and /or left unrecognized by the perpetrator, even while he recognizes the victim as capable of having experiences, interests, and desires. [106]

Therefore: not seen as “capable of contributing to epistemic practices uniquely, that is, from her own distinct lived experiences . . . she is not permitted to contribute in ways that extend beyond or trouble the veracity of the dominantly experienced world” [107]

But, what about only being seen as “capable of contributing to epistemic practices uniquely, that is, from her own distinct lived experiences”

[i.e., not through an ability to reason inferensially to a unique, non-normative conclusion]

and therefore, . . . “she is not permitted to contribute in ways that extend beyond or trouble the veracity of the dominantly experienced world”

A unique epistemic practice is one that is only subjectively true grounded not in universal experience, but subjective one.

The problem with PCE is not that one is not permitted to contribute in ways that are perceived to extend beyond dominant experiences; rather, the problem is that one is only permitted (and expected to) contribute in ways that are considered “unique” and “distinct”. [Davis 490]

title: Project Research Bible: Aesthetics of Evil
text:
Three Kinds of Tragic Conflict

Good people being ruined becuase of things that just happen to them, things they do not control.
Good people doing bad things, things opposite of their ethical character and commitments because of things they do not control.
Good people doing bad things without direct physical compulsion and opposite of their ethical character and commitments though done in light of circumstances of equally bad choices.

Agammenon is waiting on the shore with his entire fleet. He intends to carry out a directive from Zeus to avenge his brother whose wife ran away with Paris, prince of Troy. However, because of an earlier transgression against Artimis, Artimis is holding back the wind, stranding his fleet. Agammenon, as the result of an omen of an eagle devouring a hare, is told that in order to appease Artimis, he must sacrifice his daughter Iphigenia.
As such, Agammenon is faced with two impossible choices, fail to carry out Zeus’s command, or kill his daughter. It is important to point out that the fleet is already facing starvation being stranded on the coast.
However, Agammenon’s sin, is not that he choices sacrificing his daughter, instead it is the way he sacrificed his daughter.

Like in the biblical story of Abraham, a good man must kill an innocent child “out of obedience to a divine command” [35].
Agammenon’s sin however, is not the choice, but rather how the choice was made:

Agammenon now begins to cooperate inwardly with necessity, arragning his feelings to accord with his fortune.
From the moment he makes his decision, itself the best he could have made, he strangely turns himself into a collaborator, a willing victim [35].


Progression of loss of agency:

Necessity of the act
to the rightness of the act
to the rightness of the feelings of the act

The vulnerability of the Good Human Life
All human excellence requires external resources and necessary conditions.

External objects to exercise virtues towards
External objects to receive our virtues

The most important of these require relational virtues.
E.g.,

Good activities of citizenship
Political attachment
Personal love
Friendship


The Relational Harm of Slavery
Good character requires civic activity, good political surroundings.
A slave however, lacks:

choice
philia

A person needs to be able to make free and un-coerced choices. A slave is unable to do so since he belongs to someone else who makes choices for him. Owing to his inability to make free and unconstrained choices, a slave is unable to use their capacity for practical reason, choosing objects for their own sake. As such, they cannot share in philia which “is based on mutual respect for choice and character” [348].
